title: Calculation of values passed by value no longer optimzed

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: regression-from-stable-to-stable
labels.description: Performance or correctness regression from one stable version to another.

labels.name: I-heavy
labels.description: Problems and improvements with respect to binary size of generated code.

body:
### Code

The expression
```rust
if some_boolean { 1 } else { 0 }
```
is usually optimized to a single machine instruction, without branching. But when passing the result by value to some non-trivial function, such as
```rust
fn white_box(i: usize) {
    println!("{}", i)
}
```
the expression is not optimized and branches with 1 and 0 constants are written out. It used to be optimized up to Rust version 1.24, and it is still optimized when passing by reference. [This Godbolt setup](https://rust.godbolt.org/z/GhavcxhTG) compares passing by value and by reference, and shows the lack of optimization if you bump the Rust versions to something modern.

Another example of a function thwarting optimization of its argument appears to be `std::hint::black_box`.

### Version it worked on

It most recently worked on: Rust 1.24 (also tried 1.22, 1.20, 1.16).

This came up, with diagnostic detail, in [a URO quest](https://users.rust-lang.org/t/matching-vs-if-else/73564).
